bioghist.p: Damavand College, named after the mountain which rises out of the Alborz range north of the city of Tehran, was a private institution of higher learning for women, offering a four-year intercultural program in the liberal arts. The program of studies at Damavand was accredited in 1968 and its first class of seniors was graduated in 1972. The school began as the Iran Bethel Educational Project and was transformed under the direction of Dr. Frances M. Gray into a four-year liberal arts college. Damavand moved from central Tehran to a new campus on Lashgarak Road in north Tehran in 1975. Dr. Mary C. Thompson was the academic dean of Damavand College, and was involved in the school from its inception.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers related to Damavand College (Tehran) compiled by Mary C. Thompson. Materials include: newspaper and magazine articles; reprints and papers of Damavand professors; promotional brochures, catalogs, and bulletins; presidents' reports; commencement programs; yearbooks (1968, 1973, 1977, 1978); newsletters; correspondence from faculty and others associated with the college (1978-1988); address lists of faculty members and alumnae; photographs and slides of students; material related to commencement ceremonies; and papers related to the dissolution of Damavand College Foundation (includes financial material and minutes), 1990. The collection also includes a memoir by Ruth E. Harman about her time in Iran (1931-1936 and 1955-1971). Daguerreotype portraits of Lizzie Cooper and Mrs. R.D. Thompson are housed in with the daguerreotype collection.
